steps.explanation: Keeping up to date with COVID-19 vaccines is crucial, especially for older adults and those with underlying health conditions, as it significantly reduces the risk of severe illness, hospitalization, and death.

Adhering to general preventive measures, such as masking and social distancing, is important, especially for individuals at higher risk due to age or underlying medical conditions, to minimize exposure and transmission.

citations.excerpt:
People with Certain Medical Conditions and COVID-19 Risk Factors
For Everyone
June 11, 2025
Español
What to know
• If you have any medical conditions listed below, you are more likely to get very sick
with COVID-19.
• This list does not include all conditions.
• If you have symptoms consistent with ...

steps.text: Seek treatment within 5-7 days of symptom onset.
steps.explanation: Initiating treatment early, specifically within 5 to 7 days from when symptoms first appear, is crucial. Early intervention can significantly lower the chances of needing hospitalization and reduce the risk of death associated with COVID-19.

steps.text: Consider visiting a Test to Treat location.
steps.explanation: Test to Treat locations offer the convenience of getting tested for COVID-19 and receiving treatment, if eligible, in one visit. This can expedite access to necessary medications and care.

steps.text: Discuss vaccination with a healthcare provider.
steps.explanation: Parents of children aged 6 months to 17 years should consult with a healthcare provider to discuss the benefits of COVID-19 vaccination. Vaccination is a key preventive measure, especially for children and teens with underlying medical conditions.

Specific information on children and teens
People of all ages, including children and teens, can get very sick from COVID-19,
especially those with underlying medical conditions. This includes children and teens with:
• Medical complexity
• Genetic, neurologic, or metabolic cond...

steps.text: Vaccinate children and teens against COVID-19.
steps.explanation: Parents of children ages 6 months to 17 years should discuss the benefits of COVID-19 vaccination with a healthcare provider to protect them from severe illness.

steps.text: Consult a healthcare provider about managing conditions.
steps.explanation: If you have questions about managing a medical condition or protecting yourself from COVID-19, consult your healthcare provider for specific advice.

steps.explanation: For immunocompromised individuals aged 12+ and weighing at least 88 pounds, discuss the possibility of using Pemivibart, a monoclonal antibody, for added protection against COVID-19. Note that Pemgarda is not a treatment but a preventive measure.

steps.text: Maintain vaccination schedule in immunocompromised patients.
steps.explanation: Ensure that immunocompromised individuals receive updated COVID-19 vaccines, as they may still be vulnerable even when vaccinated. Additional doses may be beneficial based on specific guidelines due to their potentially different immune response.

steps.text: Consult healthcare provider about additional precautions.
steps.explanation: Advise immunocompromised individuals to discuss with their healthcare provider about any additional precautions that may be necessary based on their specific condition and treatment regimen, as vaccines may not provide full protection.

citations.excerpt:
omised condition or weakened immune system
People who are immunocompromised or are taking medicines that weaken their immune
system may not be protected even if they are up to date on their vaccines. Examples
include:
• People who have cancer and are on chemotherapy
• People who have had a solid org...

steps.text: Consult healthcare provider about extra precautions.
steps.explanation: Immunocompromised individuals, even when vaccinated, may require additional preventive measures. Discuss specific risks and needs with a healthcare provider to determine appropriate steps.
Moderately or severely immunocompromised individuals might benefit from extra doses of the updated COVID-19 vaccine due to potentially different immune responses.
Individuals 12 years and older, weighing at least 88 pounds, and moderately or severely immunocompromised may be eligible for Pemivibart, a monoclonal antibody for COVID-19 protection.

steps.text: Administer Pemivibart at least 2 weeks post-vaccination.
steps.explanation: If eligible, ensure Pemivibart is given at least two weeks after a COVID-19 vaccine to provide an additional layer of protection. Note that Pemivibart is not a treatment for COVID-19.
